#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Penticton
#Text=Penticton ( The ' Peach City ' ) is a beautiful spot in the south Okanagan nestled between two lakes : The 155-km-long Okanagan Lake to the north , and the smaller Skaha Lake to the south .
#Text=Tourism in Penticton is largely seasonal .
#Text=In the summer tourists double Penticton 's population to 60,000 .
#Text=In the winter things used to be very quiet , but now that World Cup Freestyle Skiing stops at local Apex Mountain every winter , the winter scene is picking up .
#Text=Understand
#Text=This area has been inhabited for thousands of years by the Salish group of First Nations people .
#Text=They called their settlement in this area Snpinkten which translates as ' a place to stay forever ' and gives Penticton its name .
#Text=The first non-native settler Thomas Ellis preempted land in Penticton in 1869 and started a very successful cattle ranch .
#Text=With the arrival of engineering marvel Kettle Valley Railway the boom in Penticton had begun .
#Text=Penticton became a municipality in 1908 , and a city in 1948 .
#Text=Penticton 's climate is well suited for agriculture , and thousands of fruit trees were planted all along the west and east bench areas overlooking Okanagan Lake .
#Text=From cherries in early July to apples and pears in early September , Penticton has always been a large producer and exporter of non-citrus tree fruit .

#Text=Many local oldtimers decry the trend of ripping out perfectly healthy and productive orchards for the more lucrative vineyards which supply grapes for the regions more than thirty boutique wineries .
#Text=Today Penticton 's two largest industries are tourism and the growing wine industry , which threatens to eclipse the fruit production industry .
#Text=Penticton 's climate and geography is a northern , four-seasons version of what some call Mediterranean .
#Text=Large clay banks , benches , and scrubland skirt the mid-level mountains that frame the valley on the east and west sides .
#Text=Summers are hot with an average temperature of 27°C , and peaks of 35-40°C are not unheard of .
#Text=The large size of Okanagan Lake tempers the climate in winter which sees an average high of 0.9°C in January .
#Text=It can and does snow occasionally , but generally only during December and January will it accumulate in modest quantities .
#Text=You can check the snow level with a quick glance to the mountains , which will have a white apron about half to three-quarters of the way up .
#Text=Penticton gets about 2000 hours of sun per year , which is a higher average than Rio de Janeiro .
#Text=By car
#Text=Most travellers will arrive in Penticton by automobile .
#Text=Highway 97 is the major north-south route through the city .
#Text=Travel times are about 4 hours from Vancouver , 8 hours from Calgary and 5 hours from Seattle or Spokane .
#Text=Penticton is a 40-minute drive south from Kelowna .
#Text=The US/Canada border crossing to the south on Highway 97 is open 24 hours a day ; other border crossings in this region are closed overnight .
#Text=By bus
#Text=BC Transit operates Route 60 which runs once in each direction between Osoyoos and Kelowna , stopping in Penticton , on weekdays .
#Text=By plane
#Text=Penticton Regional Airport ( YYF ) .
#Text=Is a small airport with domestic flights from Vancouver .
#Text=It is at the south end of town off Hwy 97 .
#Text=U.S. and some international flights will land in Kelowna , 60 km to the north .
#Text=Most international flights will land in Vancouver where an alternate mode of transportation will be needed to reach Penticton .
#Text=There are no scheduled commercial flights between Kelowna and Penticton ; however , you may charter a flight with Carson Air or Southern Skies .
#Text=Air Canada Express provides air service to Vancouver .
#Text=Southern Skies Aviation , Penticton Airport , ☏ +1250 492-0074 .
#Text=provides aircraft charters for transportation and sightseeing
#Text=By car
#Text=This is your best bet if you wish to visit the area 's many wineries , which are generally out of town a ways .
#Text=Car rentals :
#Text=Best Choice Car Rentals , 249 Westminster Ave. , ☏ +1250 490-3339 .
#Text=Budget Car and Truck Rentals , two locations : 188 Westminster Ave West , Penticton Airport , +1 250 493-0212.
#Text=By bus
#Text=BC Transit operates a local bus service in Penticton with five regular routes and a night route .
#Text=Service ends at 7PM for regular routes and 10PM for the night route .
#Text=There is no service on Sundays except for the Lake-to-lake shuttle .
#Text=Fares are $ 1.75 which includes a 90-minute transfer .
#Text=Ask the operator , as they generally will not offer one .
#Text=By taxi
#Text=Penticton has two cab companies , Courtesy Taxi ( ☏ +1 250-492-7777 ) and Klassic Taxi ( ☏ +1 250-492-6666 ) , who run computerized dispatch .
#Text=Both companies provide luxury cars and six passenger vans .
#Text=They also recently introduced the wheelchair vans .
#Text=On foot and bike
#Text=Penticton 's compact size lends itself to biking or even just walking around .
#Text=It will take about 15 minutes to bike from lake to lake , and just over an hour for the same journey on foot .
#Text=There are walking and biking trails on both sides of the River Channel , and a painted bike lane on a major north-south corridor of the city .
#Text=Bike rentals :
#Text=Bike Barn , 300 Westminster Ave , +1 250 492-4140. $35/day .
#Text=Freedom the Bike Shop , 533 Main Street , +1 250 493-0686. from $40/day .
#Text=See
#Text=Leir House Cultural Centre , 220 Manor Park Ave , ☏ +1250 492-7997 .
#Text=10AM-4PM .
#Text=This beautiful 1927 house was once a nurses ' residence but now serves as the home of the Penticton Arts Council .
#Text=Open to the public year round .
#Text=Worth a visit to see the grounds , with vintage stone walls and a relaxing gazebo .
#Text=Free .
#Text=Munson Mountain Park , Munson Mountain Rd ( from town , head east on Vancouver Ave and follow the signs ) .
#Text=The home to the large ' Penticton ' sign ( a la ' Hollywood ' ) that greets travelers coming in to town from the north .
#Text=The sign was created with thousands of small white stones .
#Text=The original stones have since been replaced with letters made of concrete .
#Text=The park itself affords visitors with stunning 360 degree panoramas of the South Okanagan valley .
#Text=Views to the south are accessed by an easy paved trail to the lookout .
#Text=The panoramic views require walking up the hill , but there are plenty of benches to rest at and take in the view .
#Text=Penticton Art Gallery ( formerly the Art Gallery of the South Okanagan ) , 199 Marina Way , ☏ +1250 493-2928 .
#Text=Tu - F 10AM-5PM , Sa - Su 11AM-4PM .
#Text=Contains a modest permanent collection of work by local and area artists as well as bone carvings by traditional Inuit artists .
#Text=Also features moving exhibits and other special events .
#Text=$ 2 for adults Tu - F , free otherwise .
#Text=Penticton Museum & Archives , 785 Main St , ☏ +1250 490-2451 .
#Text=Tu - Sa 10AM-5PM .
#Text=Features over 8000 artifacts , photographs , and documents that tell the story of Penticton 's pioneers days , as well as local First Nations pieces .
#Text=Located in the same building as the Penticton Regional Library .
#Text=There is a gift shop on site .
#Text=Suggested donation $ 2 .
#Text=The Penticton Roundabout ( junction of Front Street , Ellis Street , Marina Way , and Vancouver Hill ) features changing art installations .
#Text=A work nicknamed Frank ( actually called The Baggage Handler ) was moved because of vandalism and controversy with local puritans due to the anatomical correctness of the piece .
#Text=Today you can see Frank at his permanent home at Red Rooster Winery , and the roundabout has a less contentious piece .
#Text=S.S. Sicamous , 1099 Lakeshore Dr West ( the west end of Lakeshore Drive ) , ☏ +1250 492-0403 , ✉ mail@sssicamous.com .
#Text=9AM-9PM in high summer , shorter hours at other seasons .
#Text=This paddlewheeler was the last commercial ship to operate on Okanagan Lake .
#Text=Built in 1914 and retired in 1936 , the large ship now spends its days drydocked on the edge of Okanagan Lake .
#Text=The ship is open daily for tours in the summer , and includes a large HO scale model railway on the main deck , depicting the local Kettle Valley Railway .
#Text=The smaller S.S. Naramata rests just behind the Sicamous .
#Text=Adults $ 6 , seniors and youth $ 4.50 , children 7-13 $ 3.50 , children 6 and under free .
#Text=The Peach , foot of Winnipeg St on Okanagan Lake .
#Text=A concession stand shaped and painted as a giant peach .
#Text=While it is n't that interesting in and of itself , it has an interesting history and is one of the most photographed spots in town .
#Text=Film buffs may recognize it from the movie My American Cousin which was filmed in the Penticton Area .
#Text=This is the second Peach , as the first was pushed into the lake during the 1990 Peachfest riot ( The riot was an isolated incident , Penticton is really quite safe . )
